Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: “Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization,”
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: They said it correctly identifies problems with L.A. rent control and validates their demands for stronger limits.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: “The report shows that rent costs exceeding what tenants can pay is a primary cause of homelessness,”
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: They point to other L.A.-area cities that currently limit rent increases to less than 3% with no add-ons for utilities.; We are obviously in a homelessness crisis in L.A., and if this formula isn't updated soon, more folks will just fall into homelessness.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: “There are plenty of owners out there who have had their renters in place for many years,”
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: They strongly disputed the report’s conclusions.; Landlord advocates say some property owners have yet to fully recover from the pandemic.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: About 35% of the rent L.A. tenants pay goes to operating expenses for apartment buildings, on average.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.; The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: From January 2020 through January 2023, 4 in 10 rent-controlled L.A. apartments became vacant.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.; The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: About one-fifth of L.A. renters are living below the federal poverty line.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.; The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The city’s current range of allowable annual rent increases — anywhere from 3% to 8% depending on inflation — is higher than the increases permitted in most other California cities with rent control.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.; The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year
